entry.title: Book: Nutrition and Physical Degeneration, by Weston A. Price (1939)
entry.content:
Book: Nutrition and Physical Degeneration, by Weston A. Price (1939)20130504
My wife requested that I read this and write a summary for her
because she didn't want to read it herself.

I read up past the Introduction today, which means I just read the
rhetorical preview of what is covered without reading any of the
details. When I was vegan, I read lots of stuff like this about
how wonderful primitive diets were, especially with regards to
teeth. I'm interested in learning the details.

The introduction was very funny with its discussion of how the
bones in the head were affected by nutrition and in turn affected
brain development. And its discussion of "delinquents".
  • Books
  • 1939

entry.title: Game: Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 4 Golden (Vita, 2012) (9)
entry.content:
Game: Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 4 Golden (Vita, 2012) (9)20130503
I did a bunch of grinding today for about two and a half hours,
but I got to the point in the Bathhouse where I could just walk
over every enemy group. Generally what I do in these games is
grind until I run out of SP and can't heal anymore. But, once I
get strong enough, it seems like I can last indefinitely because
I get blue cards after battle and can't just do physical damage
to everything to win.

I did a little bit more social stuff, including getting my stats
to the point where I could continue with Nanako.

Total time: 21:59
  • Video Games
  • Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 4 Golden
  • Vita
  • 2012

entry.title: Game: Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 4 Golden (Vita, 2012) (8)
entry.content:
Game: Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 4 Golden (Vita, 2012) (8)20130502
I played for two-ish hours. I didn't do much socially, but with
what I did, I'm finding that I don't have high enough stats to
continue along with some people or do the part-time jobs that give
you access to other characters. I had a day with nothing to do, so
I went into the TV and beat the Castle King then went and grinded
in the Bathhouse. I found a nice strategy for getting a ton of
Sweep Bonuses. It's fun.

Total time: 19:22

entry.title: Movie: Broken City, starring Mark Wahlberg (2013)
entry.content:
Movie: Broken City, starring Mark Wahlberg (2013)20130428
Markie Mark and Russell Crowe were great in this movie. I like the
subterfuge. I really liked the debate scene and I thought that
Billy's reaction to his girlfriend's movie was very
true. Unfortunately, the "good guy" was a wuss and communist. I was
surprised that they attempted to put in a relationship between
Billy and Katy.

entry.title: Game: Final Fantasy 5 (SNES, 1992) (4)
entry.content:
Game: Final Fantasy 5 (SNES, 1992) (4)20130423
Yesterday, I reached an ideal ABP grinding spot and satisfied
about half of my overall job planning goals. I still had about
half left and a total of about 1000 ABP left to get. I calculated
my ABP efficiency:
- Always get 4 or 8 ABP per fight
- Always win every fight because Galuf has highest speed and can
always cast Lvl 5 Doom
- Can do 8 fights for every use of a Cabin to get back MP
- A Cabin costs 600 GP
- Each fight gives 1014 GP or 2535 GP
- Each fight gives 50 XP or 125 XP

This means that every cycle of fights, I get, assuming equal
numbers of two statue and five statue fights:
- 48 ABP
- 13596 GP
- 700 XP

Since this process has no risk, it is essentially an arbitrage
opportunity in the game to get infinite resources.

This means that it would take about 21 cycles to get all my ABP
requirements satisfied. I would also net 285k GP and 14700 XP. This
would only bring me up two levels (I'm 25 now), which is not a
significant source of XP. It's also about double my gold.  I
estimate that this would take about four hours to do, based on
getting about 500 ABP in two hours.

When there are situations like this in a game, I wish it were
possible to give the game a proof or a program that it was possible
for me to get the resources, so I didn't have to actually spend my
time to it. It seems wrong to spend my valuable time on such
things.

Putting all this together, I decided to dump the SRAM from my
PowerPak and then wrote a program to adjust my total ABP to
expedite this process. It was a little complicated to find where
they were stored and then adjust the checksums. (The key was that
the SNES is little endian.) Implementing the program and running it
took about an hour and a half... which is still a time win.

After doing this, I got all my ABP, but didn't get any of the XP or
the GP. Although this is definitely not "allowed" in the game, I
consider it a fair trade that doesn't compromise the integrity of
my play-through too much.

I then switch to Freelancers, got my Abilities all in line, and
then got the equipment from the store that I wanted. (Nice thing:
The chain whip is the most powerful weapon I have available right
now and it is also usable from the back row!)

This whole process took 8 minutes of game time, which I will count,
and about an hour and a half of programming time.

Total time: 15:00
  • Video Games
  • Final Fantasy 5
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Game: Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 4 Golden (Vita, 2012)
entry.content:
Game: Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 4 Golden (Vita, 2012)20130423
I played this for three and a half hours and got up to unlocking
Chie. I basically saw the same sequence that I had previously
watched at the beginning of the Giantbomb Endurance Run, which I
did not finish. I really like the dialogue and the voice
actors. It's fun. I've only had like three fights and no ability
to use the mechanics, so I can't comment on them yet. It seems
very similar to P3P, which I liked a lot.

Total time: 3:21

entry.title: Book: Emma, by Jane Austen (1815)
entry.content:
Book: Emma, by Jane Austen (1815)20130423
I read the first four chapters of this on a flight. I really like
this novel, because Emma is such an interesting and different
heroine. I've read it so many times and seen Clueless so many
times, it is very hard for me to not think of them at the same
time, which I think it is very funny.
  • Books
  • 1815

entry.title: Game: Final Fantasy 5 (SNES, 1992) (3)
entry.content:
Game: Final Fantasy 5 (SNES, 1992) (3)20130422
I played for about two and half hours today. The first half was
wandering around in the new world until I ran into the forest
where you meet the moogles. Moogles are so cute and I'm glad they
were introduced in this game... yet another thing that FF5 started
and shares with FF6. I love their song.

Next, I got to Galuf's castle and spent a lot of time grinding in
the basement. I'm closing to getting my characters to the point of
being Freelancers. Well, about half-way. I think I'm done grinding
jobs now because I have a good repertoire that will last for a
long time.

Also, I'm about to leave on a trip, so I'll be away from my SNES
for a while. When I get back, I doubt I'll want to spend the time
grinding... although maybe a little to get back into the feel of
the game.

Total time: 14:52
  • Video Games
  • Final Fantasy 5
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Game: Final Fantasy 5 (SNES, 1992) (2)
entry.content:
Game: Final Fantasy 5 (SNES, 1992) (2)20130421
I played for most of this morning and go to the first town of
Galuf's world. I still haven't really ventured outside the first
few jobs, because I'm focusing on mastering them. Most of the jobs
that seem exciting, like Dragoon, aren't really that good when you
read the details about them.

Some of the bosses in this game are really finicky with the random
number generator. For example, the boss of the Ancient *REDACTED*rary
creamed me the first four times, then when I prepared a new
strategy, he never even attacked! He just used status effects and
didn't make use of them.

Something annoying about this game (and almost all other RPGs)
after playing Mystic Quest is that you can't jump over people who
are in your way!

When I learned about Butz' history, it was a little to awkward
for his dad to yell, "Stella!"

Finally, after getting the airship, I found it very confusing what
I was supposed to do... I just wandered around trying to find new
places to go... eventually I accidentally discovered you had to go
/back/ to the ruins.

I think next time I play I'll have to grind a little, because I'm
finding the random battles taking too much out of me.

Total time: 12:18
  • Video Games
  • Final Fantasy 5
  • SNES
  • 1992
